entry.title: (施工中) 翻译：得到辩护的真信念就是知识吗？
entry.content:

Original: Edmund Gettier: Is Justified True Belief Knowledge? (Click to view Pdf, From Analysis. vol. 23 (] 966). Copyright @ by Edmund Gettier. Reprinted by permission of the author. )

Translator: Tracy Tsui

埃德蒙-盖蒂尔是马萨诸塞大学阿默斯特分校的名誉教授。对许多人来说，这篇发表于1963年的短文似乎根本驳斥了一个本来很有吸引力的对知识的分析[1]。这篇文也让人们开始重新讨论知识的定义。

Various attempts have been made in recent years to state necessary and sufficient conditions for someone’s knowing a given proposition. The attempts have often been such that they can be stated in a form similar to the following:

(a) S knows that P IFF (i.e., if and only if) (i) P is true, (ii) S believes that P, and (iii) S is justified in believing that P. For example, Chisholm has held that the following gives the necessary and sufficient conditions for knowledge:2 (b) S knows that P IFF (i.e., if and only if) (i) S accepts P, (ii) S has adequate evidence for P, and (iii) P is true. Ayer has stated the necessary and sufficient conditions for knowledge as follows:3 (c) S knows that P IFF (i) P is true, (ii) S is sure that P is true, and (iii) S has the right to be sure that P is true. I shall argue that (a) is false in that the conditions stated therein do not constitute a sufficient condition for the truth of the proposition that S knows that P. The same argument will show that (b) and (c) fail if “has adequate evidence for” or “has the right to be sure that” is substituted for “is justified in believing that” throughout. I shal1 begin by noting two points. First, in that sense of “justified” in which S’s being justified in believing P is a necessary condition of S’s knowing that P, it is possible for a person to be justified in believing a proposition that is in fact false. Secondly, for any proposition P, if S is justified in believing P, and P entails Q, and S deduces Q from P and accepts Q as a result of this deduction, then S is justified in believing Q. Keeping these two points in mind, I shal1 now present two cases in which the conditions stated in (a) are true for some proposition, though it is at the same time false that the person in question knows that proposition. CASE I Suppose that Smith and Jones have applied for a certain job. And suppose that Smith has strong evidence for the fol1owing conjunctive proposition: (d) Jones is the man who will get the job, and Jones has ten coins in his pocket. Smith’s evidence for (d) might be that the president of the company assured him that Jones would in the end be selected, and that he, Smith, had counted the coins in Jones’s pocket ten minutes ago. Proposition (d) entails: (e) The man who will get the job has ten coins in his pocket. Let us suppose that Smith sees the entailment from (d) to (e), and accepts (e) on the grounds of (d), for which he has strong evidence. In this case, Smith is clearly justified in believing that (e) is true. But imagine, further, that unknown to Smith, he himself, not Jones, will get the job. And, also, unknown to Smith, he himself has ten coins in his pocket. Proposition (e) is then true, though proposition (d), from which Smith inferred (e), is false. In our example, then, all of the following are true: (i) (e) is true, (ii) Smith believes that (e) is true, and (iii) Smith is justified in believing that (e) is true. But it is equally clear that Smith does not KNOW that (e) is true; for (e) is true in virtue of the number of coins in Smith’s pocket, while Smith does not know how many coins are in Smith’s pocket, and bases his belief in (e) on a count of the coins in Jones’s pocket, whom he falsely believes to be the man who will get the job. CASE II Let us suppose that Smith has strong evidence for the following proposition: (f) Jones owns a Ford. Smith’s evidence might be that Jones has at all times in the past within Smith’s memory owned a car, and always a Ford, and that Jones has just offered Smith a ride while driving a Ford. Let us imagine, now, that Smith has another friend, Brown, of whose whereabouts he is totally ignorant. Smith selects three place names quite at random and constructs the following three propositions: (g) Either Jones owns a Ford, or Brown is in Boston. (h) Either Jones owns a Ford, or Brown is in Barcelona. (i) Either Jones owns a Ford, or Brown is in Brest-Litovsk. Each of these propositions is entailed by (f). Imagine that Smith realizes the entailment of each of these propositions he has constructed by (0, and proceeds to accept (g), (h), and (i) on the basis of (f). Smith has correctly inferred (g), (h), and (i) from a proposition for which he has strong evidence. Smith is therefore completely justified in believing each of these three propositions. Smith, of course, has no idea where Brown is. But imagine now that two further conditions hold. First, Jones does not own a Ford, but is at present driving a rented car. And secondly, by the sheerest coincidence, and entirely unknown to Smith, the place mentioned in proposition (h) happens really to be the place where Brown is. If these two conditions hold, then Smith does not KNOW that (h) is true, even though (i) (h) is true, (ii) Smith does believe that (h) is true, and (iii) Smith is justified in believing that (h) is true. These two examples show that definition (a) does not state a sufficient condition for someone’s knowing a given proposition. The same cases, with appropriate changes, will suffice to show that neither definition (b) nor definition (c) do so either. NOTES 1. Plato seems to be considering some such definition at Theaetetus 20 I, and perhaps accepting one at Meno 98. 2. Roderick M. Chisholm, Perceiving: A Philosophical Study. (Ithaca, N.Y., 1957), 16. 3. A. J. Ayer. The Problem of Knowledge (London, 1956).

  1. 1.即JTB理论。——译者注 ↩

entry.title: 翻译：七个步骤写出更好的哲学论文
entry.content:
Translations are for academic studying only. Do not copy or cite from this post for both (formal) academic and commercial uses. The copyright is retained by the original author, and I abjure the never-existed copyright of translation.

Original: Bryan W. Roberts: 7 Steps to a Better Philosophy Paper (Click to View PDF)

Translator: Tracy Tsui

1. 开始你的分析

哲学是一门有趣、有深度、有感染力的学科；花时间沉浸在思考与记录之中，能让你写下思绪时不那么费时费神。

第一步·准确地表达问题，思考一下，然后再想一想

如果是命题论文，吃午餐的时候把题目记在餐巾纸上，跟你的朋友解释一下这个问题，想一些其他能等价表达这个问题的方法。可能的答案是什么？不同的答案如何遴选？要记得只有回答你所被指派到的那个问题。如果不是命题论文，就自己提出一个有趣的问题。这能帮助你不偏离主题。

第二步·读（然后重读）和你所想的问题相关的学术文本

课上的阅读材料可能跟问题有关，所以在你读和重读的时候，思考一下你的问题。为你自己总结一下这些作者的论点，然后记下其优势劣势。复习课堂笔记可能也会有帮助。虽然你要写的是你自己的论点，但讨论其他作者的观点也可能帮到你。

你可以自己去找其他资料，只要它是“学术的”。谷歌学术（Google Scholar）就是个不错的资源。你也可以从课上材料中的参考文献里找来读。

第三步·写下或者修改你的一两句中心论点

写下你的中心论点（thesis statement）：这，也只有这将会是你所要论证的。但此时它也不是固定不变的；随着你继续分析你的问题，你将可能修改你的中心论点。但无论如何你得记得你所要论证的到底是什么。它必须准确、清晰，且不能超过两句话。你的论点可能有两部分，比如一个负面主张（negative claim）和一个正面主张（positive claim），但它一定要短。这是个例子：

我将论证Lauden对历史的呼吁并不能成为拒绝科学现实主义的理由，但对其观点稍加修改就可以。

第四步·以论证的形式组织你的论据

这是你写作过程最重要的一部分——多花点时间在这上面！你的论点必须拥有无懈可击的论证。如果你不能确保你的论证足够好，就回去修改一下你的论点。

你可以先头脑风暴，把所有你认为能证明你的论文的主张（claims）都列出来，然后用前提-结论（premise-conclusion）形式写下一个论点。比如这个苏格拉底提出的一个论点是神圣与神无关（holiness has nothing to do with god）的：

如果你的论点能被正确地组织好，这些前提一定能得出结论。现在你剩下的任务就是为每个前提提供尽可能多的支撑，确保每个前提都有你能想到的最好的支持。现在你准备开始写作了。

2. 把它们写进去

写哲学论点需要你的十分谨慎和精确，但当你做对的时候回报颇丰。你尽可以忘掉你在创意写作课上学的大多数东西。一篇哲学论文的目标应该仅仅是为你的论点清晰而信服地论证，仅此而已。

第五步·把提纲列出来，包含一个导论节、一个主体节和一个结论节

导论（introduction）应包括对问题的简要讨论、陈述中心论点、以及关于你将如何论证该中心论点的一些评论。主体（main body）应包含对相关背景信息的描述以及对中心论点的论证。结论（conclusion）应包含中心论点的重述以及（可选）对未尽事宜的一些简要评论，例如今后在这个主题上还有哪些工作要做。你的提纲应该包含对一些你用到的学术材料的相关引用。这份文档将帮助你更有效地撰写论文。

第六步·先写主体节，然后导论，最后结论

先写主体节是因为它是最切题也是最难的部分。你应该相当清楚你结论的各个前提是什么，以及它们如何得出你的中心论点。对每个前提都要花时间解释清楚。这样当你之后开始写导论结论的时候，你对你论点的总结就会更准确。在整个过程中都要紧跟着你的论文提纲和论点提纲。不要忘了带上一个参考节，以及——除非真的是很琐碎的常识——每一个信息都需要有引用！

第七步·把论文在旁边放个一两天，然后再拿起来修改

这就是合格的论文和优秀的论文的差别。如果你给你时间消化你所写下的东西，并用一副更新鲜的眼睛去阅读它，你几乎总是能找到改进你论文的新方法。

3. 写哲学的十大注意事项

这些注意事项是基于一些常见错误给出的。时刻检查你是否有考虑到这些事项能帮你写出一篇更好的哲学论文。

  1. 早点开始。有的时候有些事情你可能即使拖到最后一分钟再去做也能做得还不错——但在哲学里这种情况极度罕见。哲学需要时间去反思。
  2. 读材料的时候记笔记。写下你对有关学术材料的思考，简要记一下你的想法。写提纲的时候把这些笔记放在你面前。
  3. 聚焦问题，聚焦答案。你所写的一切东西都是为了解决你的问题。你的中心论点一定是在回答那个问题。你的论证一定支持你的中心论点。一切其他东西都是无关紧要的！
  4. 把你的读者当作傻子。你可能会认为你的教授在读过那么多哲学以后，能一下子抓到你论文的重点和建议……实际上，我们没那么聪明。把你的论文写得就像你在向一个十足的小丑解释你的观点一样。文章的每一点展开得越透彻越好。
  5. 不要试图涵盖太多。一篇好的哲学论文只会说一些朴素而谦逊的东西，然后好好地论证它们。不要试图在一份五页纸的论文里解决那些大问题！
  6. 随时在论文里提一嘴你现在在做什么。一定要保持让读者清楚你现在在论证哪一部分。每一段落的目的对于读者都必须是侮辱人地一清二楚。比如，你可以说[1]：
    • 我的论证会是如下形式。首先……
    • 我将会在以下范围论证我的中心论点：
    • 在验证完毕这两个前提之后，我现在将说明我的最后一个前提为真。
    • 关于这点，一个好的例子是……
    • 对于这个反对的一个回应是……
    • 作为上述论证的结果，我们可以得出……
  7. 使用过简洁的语言。不要用太长的、华丽的语言，除非你必须如此。太口语的用词也不合适；但你的句子应该简短易读。在哲学论文里你可以自由地用我（I）指代自己，尤其是当你指出现在你在进行论证的哪一部分的时候。
  8. 如果你不能支撑某一句话，不要写它。任何一个不是荒谬地显而易见的句子都必须有支撑，且不是通过仅仅说“我相信……”你必须通过给出论证、考虑其他情况、提供例子、引用资料等等来说服你的观众。避免诸如“自从时间伊始，人类就开始……”的句子，因为你并不看起来能很好地支撑这句话。
  9. 只用学术参考。哲学术语很有可能拥有你在其他领域或者字典里找不到的一些精确或者技术的意义。和学术资源紧紧联系，如果你不能确定，问你的教授。维基百科确实是开始学习某个东西的好地方，但它并不适合作为哲学论文的引用。
  10. 保持引用，但是重新组织语言，也不要过度引用。在一篇五页的论文里能引用几句是不错的，但一定要重新组织你的语言。总之不要忘了，任何不是你自己的词和想法都必须有引用。
  1. 1.请多参考原文的这一部分。——译者注 ↩

entry.title: The Joy Luck Club
entry.content:
Images in this article are not officially screenshot. The color tone is modified. Copyrights belong to its original.

I died 60 years ago.

I ate opium, and I died

For my daughter’s sake.

I shall score it 3/5, because as a Hollywood movie, the camera language is too ordinary; the narratives are like animal novels; the lines (particularly the mandarin part) are far not distinguish[1].

But there are still extraordinary portions: the scenes are beautiful; the outfits are beautiful; the music is beautiful. Such a vibe immediately warms up the depressed story. The color of contemporary mainland China at the end of the film is so an especial example that merely staring at the lens sheds my nostalgic tears. Middle-aged women’s face is forever a pathos once it becomes soft.

I daren’t blame too much for the plot, for I haven’t ever read the original book. The points that the actors’ skills showing up are bizarre, and the points that resonate me and eventually make me lose my mind are bizarre as well. They are not necessarily continuous. Anyway, too slow, too sluggish, too many leftovers. In total it is 138mins, but I think 120mins is fairly enough.

Another outstanding thing is the ambiguity of contradictions. It veils the whole movie with superrealism after covering it with the luster of orientalism, which confuses the audience because they will not know how but still be touched, feeling the surrounded atmosphere everywhere and wiping their eyes.

The hidden white supremacism theme can hardly run away from being criticized. It actually cannot be easily observed unless the observer is sensitive enough, because it is at certain extend extremely real that it successfully lurks itself among the collective unconscious of the groups and then secretly cathected towards the signifiers. Of course I believe no one was on his or her purpose to discriminate the American Chinese community, for it is solely a defending device drawn from a bitter primal scene.

But at least, I think it do owns its capacity of storing such enormous contents: women’s moral, child brides, polygamy, suicide, obsequies, flesh soup of daughter, baby killing, baby abandoning, war; male gaze, expect, hope, financial equal, independence; table manners, racism, every look, every behave, the joy luck club. For hundreds of years, the tears of mothers and daughters never end.

西山迟暮

驿下人一酌一沽

杯倾盏倒风萧
垂帘熄灭枭嗥
然后千年一叹
拍栏杆望秋宵

entry.title: 金缕衣：记自百越归于栈隔离十三夜
entry.content:
梦里化仙去：

俯凡间，泰西病宦、九州瘟弼！于是乘飞舆辗转，哀式微而涕泣。
苦瓯溃——以为何济？有志难发当代是！
噤千民，修太平新历。唯柳月，暗中叙。

灵回肉体神归器：

泪犹漻，失魂落魄、酒浆空挹。又溯那伤心光景，教我如何不靡？但思念，荆州兴疫，还有继存的百姓。岂忧天，怯懦如四佾，枯了笔，斗斯疠！
